description: From Old French cedule (whence French cédule), from Late Latin schedula (“papyrus strip”), diminutive of Latin scheda, from Ancient Greek σχέδη (skhédē, “papyrus leaf”), from Proto-Hellenic *skʰíďďō, from Proto-Indo-European *skid-yé-ti, from *skeyd- (“to divide, split”). Doublet of cedula and cedule.
This word was historically pronounced /ˈsɛdjuːl/, /ˈsɛdʒuːl/; the pronunciations with /ʃ/ and /sk/ are due to the spelling (the latter may have been reinforced by learned influence); compare schism.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A slip of paper; a short note. [14th–17th c.]

definitionGroups.group: (law) A written or printed table of information, often forming an annex or appendix to a statute or other regulatory instrument, or to a legal contract. [from 15th c.]

entries.meaning: (US, law, often capitalized) One of the five divisions into which controlled substances are classified, or the restrictions denoted by such classification. [from 20th c.]
examples: a Schedule I drug with a high potential for abuse

entries.meaning: A serial record of items, systematically arranged.
examples: Synonyms: catalog, list, listing, register, registry, table

entries.meaning: A procedural plan, usually but not necessarily tabular in nature, indicating a sequence of operations and the planned times at which those operations are to occur. [from 19th c.]
examples: things are happening ahead of schedule

entries.meaning: (computer science) An allocation or ordering of a set of tasks on one or several resources. [from 20th c.]

verbs.description: schedule (third-person singular simple present schedules, present participle scheduling, simple past and past participle scheduled)

entries.meaning: To plan an activity at a specific date or time in the future.
examples: I'll schedule you for three-o'clock then.
The next elections are scheduled on the twentieth of November.

entries.meaning: To add a name to the list of people who are participating in something.
examples: I am scheduled for classes next month.
Synonyms: sign up, register, reserve, enroll, book

entries.meaning: (Australia, medicine) To admit (a person) to hospital as an involuntary patient under a schedule of the applicable mental health law.
examples: whether or not to schedule a patient

entries.meaning: (US) To classify as a controlled substance.
